name: Michelle Carlos
comment info:
What do you notice?
I noticed that the rate of infection from Covid in each state is substantially less than the state prisons. However, there is a difference in the rates between some states like Michigan; who have a 9x rate, and Maine; who only has a difference of 3 people per 100. 
What do you wonder?
I wonder why it differs from each state and what are the factors that make it such a different rate. Why are some states healthcare and prevention so useless that the infection rate was so high during the Covid pandemic. 
What impact does this have on you and your community?
It relates to the community because the covid pandemic was deadly and affected millions of people, therefore, by having a high rate of infection in prison, put the inmates and workers at risk. 
Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
Drastic different rates of Covid infection between all US states

comment info: the graph is intriguing

comment info:

name: Sofia
comment info: It seems like Michigan has 76 prisoners that have covid out of 100 and the lowest posotive of covid prisoners is Maine because there is only 7 I am pretty sure.

name: giorgos
comment info: As we can see in prisons there are more people with covid-19 compared to people who are out the prison. This can have many reasons. First of all the problem is that there are many people in the same area. They eat together at the same time, sleep in the same rooms 2 3 people. There are very small areas when they go out in the garden so they are all close. Also, they use the same equipment when exercising. this happens in many prisons in the same areas. There are many ways to reduce the virus in prisons but again in prisons, there will be more people with covid-19 by comparison people who are out the prison.

name: Agapi
comment info: I notice that there are more infection cases in prison than in the entire state. It is the case for almost every state except Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia. I wonder why people in prisons are differently treated, they are maybe in prison but that isn't a reason for them to get infected.  I know that it isn't easy because they are many people in one cell that sleep together, prisoners eat together, shower together... I think that maybe the three states that don't have more infections in prison, have better sanity conditions or fewer people. A good headline would be "Up to nine times more infections cases in prisons than in states "

name: Vasiliki
comment info:
The Prison’s Condition of a State show the level of its culture.
In this Graphic I noticed that Covid’s infection rates are higher into the prisons than the entire population of the state. And this is a general conclusion which concerns all the States, there are not exceptions. I would like to wonder “why” but I don’t. The fact is that Governments don’t mind about the inmates, they just left them there. They forgot that prison is not a place of punishment but a place of reintegration.

name: Everett
comment info:
Notice: I noticed that for the vast majority of states, the case rate for COVID-19 in prisons was much higher than outside of prison. States like Michigan and Arkansas had over 6x the rate of COVID in prisons.

Wonder: I wonder why so many states' prisons have much higher rates of COVID. Is it because there aren't adequate measures put in place for COVID in prisons?

Impact: There is a big impact on prison inmates because they are at a higher risk of getting COVID in prison. 

Headline:
Infection Rates in Prisons Are Substatially Higher than the General Public.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info: Just released on the New York Times Learning Network “Examining the Math and Ethics of Covid-19 in Prisons.” (Search on the Learning Network by the title.)  This Lesson of the Day analyzes the graphs, maps and data to better understand the toll of the pandemic on incarcerated populations.  In particular, it addresses the difference between count and rate and the difference between social bias and statistical bias.

comment info: I noticed that case rates in state prisons are higher than case rates in the entire state. replies.comment info:

Good wonderings about what protections persons in prisons have.  In the REveal below, you'll find a link to the article that included this graph. Also, today's NYT has an article on ICE detention centers -- "4 Takeaways From Our Investigation Into ICE’s Mishandling of Covid-19".

name: Kaitlin
comment info:
I noticed that Covid infection rates in prisons tend to be much higher than infection rates in the state populations. The states are ordered based on their case rates in prison. Michigan has the highest case rate in state prisons at 76 in 100. On the other hand, Maine has the lowest prison case rate at 7 in 100. I wonder if this has to do with the density of the state's population. Hawaii has the highest ratio of prison case rate to state population case rate; the number of prison cases to state cases is 15.8. I wonder what affec the case rate ratio and how the factors differ from the case rates themselves. I also wonder what factors cause the high infection rates in prisons. Is it that workers and visitors infect prisoners? Could it be more lenient health protocols? Since prisoners are confined to the facility, are they still given masks and vaccines? 

This impacts me and my community because I have noticed that the state case rate has fluctuated throughout the pandemic. In Massachusetts, the prison case rate is 36 in 100, whereas the case rate in the entire state is 10 in 100. I would say compared to other states, we are in the middle range. 

A headline could be, "Catching COVID Behind Bars".

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Kaitlin I also agree with this

comment info: I noticed that Nevada has 3.7x times the amount of prisons as the entire state I wonder if it is due to the fact that there are not that many prisons in the navaids prisons systems.

name: kk
comment info: I notice that the prison rate for Covid is much higher than the in-state rate.  This is shown because in the middle of the bar you can see how many times more cases occur in prison rather than in the state.  I wonder what type of chart or graph this is.  I have never seen anything like it.  I wonder if it is commonly used when showing relationships such as the one shown. This impacts community because my state's prisons have more prison cases than in state cases.  This doesn't necessarily surprise me because prisoners are most likely close to one another and kept in conditions, unlike regular people.  The main thing that this graph is showing is the relationship between Covid cases in prison vs. in state.  Catchy headline: Prison infections compared to People infections

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: I think this is due to the prisons having a more confined space and less health protocols resulting in more cases being found in prisons.

HI, @kk --

This is called a connected dot plot.  

Do you think it effectively shows the difference between a state’s general population’s and prison’s infection rates?  Does it make it easy to compare states?  

What other type of graph could display the same information?  Since you have the data here, you could make the other type of graph and compare the two data visualizations.  Which one better shows “what’s going on in this graph?”

name: Mia
comment info:
What I notice: 
1. I notice that in all the states the case rate in prisons is higher than the case rate in the entire state.
2. I notice that there is not much correlation with the case rate in the entire state and the case rate in just the prisons. For example, the case rate in the prisons is going down faster than the case rate in the entire state.
What I wonder: 
1. I wonder if people can wear masks and social distance in prisons. If not, is that why the case rate in prisons are higher? 
2. When was this? Was it when Covid just started or was it like in the middle of Covid?
3. Does the population affect the case rate in the entire state?
4. Does the number of prisons affect the case rate in the prisons in the state? 
Impact On my Community: 
My community has around 8 times more prison case rates than in the entire state and Covid also impacts everyone.
 A headline could be: 
Prison's rate against State's rate: Who does Covid impact the most?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mia --

Thank you for your noticings, wonderings, impact statement and headline.  Here’s some questions for you based on what you responded.  

You notice that “the case rate in the prisons is going down faster than the case rate in the entire state.”  What does this infer?  

You wonder “When was this? Was it when Covid just started or was it like in the middle of Covid?”  Your answer is in the paragraph below the graph.

name: Ava
comment info:
What I notice:
- The state prison rates seem to be higher than the case rate in the entire state, perhaps because prisons are more confined (less open) 
- Only about 6 states have less state prison rates than case rates in the entire state, though they’re quite close
- Those 6 states have the least state and prison case rates in the US 
What I wonder:
* How come the state prison rates are higher than the case rate in the entire state?
* Do they wear masks in the prisons along with other precautions such as social distancing? 
* What time period was this? Was it when COVID was just starting or was it at the peak?
* Does the number of prisons impact the state prison case rates? 

In my community, we have about 8x more state prison rates than case rates in the entire state.

A headline could be: States VS. Prisons; which one will have more COVID cases?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Ava Maybe the sate prison rates are higher than the case rates in the entire state because prison sections are small so people are able to catch Covid more easily. I also like your headline, I think it captures the graph's main idea and I think that it is also very Catchy.

HI, @Ava --

“States VS. Prisons; which one will have more COVID cases?”  These connected dot plots certainly answer that question.  Can you think of a headline that digs deeper into what these graphs show?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Zali lawrence --

Lots to notice and wonder in these graphs.  
You notice “the orange numbers range from 1-40.”  I notice that the orange number range from 7 to 76.  What do these numbers represent?  (There’s a label above “76.”)

You wonder why “states who have more freedom and fewer regulations have a lower infection rate.”  Which states are you referring to?  What evidence of this is there in the graph?

Why do you think prisoners usually do not wear PPE?
You comment that “Also if someone is let out of jail I could catch covid because prisons have higher covid rates.”  How about the people who work in the prisons?  They come and go daily.  Could you get infected from them?

name: Clare
comment info: What I notice right away is that generally, prisons have had many more cases of COVID-19 infection than the entire state's cases. This is shown in the graph because you can see that the majority of states' prisons have 2-9x as many cases of COVID-19 as the entire state. I wonder what the effects would be if action was taken to help solve this issue. Does the government have the resources to help? If we helped improve the issue of COVID-19 in prisons, would it take away from other citizens in need of those resources? This has an impact on me and my community because my state's prisons have almost 5x as many cases as my entire state. It also impacts my community and state government as a whole as we discover what can be done to solve this problem. After reading this graph and investigating it, I think an appropriate name would be, COVID-19 Infections; Population or Prison?

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Clare i like your headline, because we're comparing the covid infections between the state case rates (population) vs. prison case rates (prison), so i think that your headline captures the idea of the graph well

replies.comment info:
HI, @mrs.rooker --

Great noticings, but be careful.  There are not cases, but case rates.  How is this different?

name: Nathan
comment info: This graph is showing the ten industries that are predicted to be in the most demand and the ten industries that are predicted to be in the least demand after Covid. I notice that costumer service representatives as a whole are predicted to be in much lower demand. I wonder why it's predicted that public transportation employees are going to be in low demand as public transportation is going to continue to be important after Covid, especially in bigger cities. I think this just means that as a whole the world was already on a path to becoming more dependent on the internet for things, but with Covid, we became even more dependent on the internet.

name: Ellie
comment info: I noticed that the rate of COVID-19 inflection in prison is generally higher than the state inflection rate; only 3 states have a higher state inflection rate than a prison infection rate. I wonder when this data was gathered and over what time period it was gathered over.  I wonder if steps were taken to reduce the drastic gaps that exist in many states. This impacts my community through state funding. In order to reduce the COVID contraction rates in prisons, there will most likely need to be an increase in spending to afford the required measures. Thus, in order to attempt to keep the state budget balanced, other funding will have to be cut, which could further impact education funding cuts (such as the 2020 temporary Oklahoma State Department of Education reduction of 2.5% or about $78.2 million). This will have a profound secondary impact on children's educational attainment levels and prospective future income attainment levels and the potential for long-run economic growth (as education level is a shifter of the Long-run aggregate supply curve which measures long-run economic growth). Catchy Headline: Prisoners vs. the Population: who's more likely to be infected by COVID-19?
